Disturbing reports from countries still enforcing ‘Zero Covid’ show this dangerous fallacy for what it is. 

Proud that the UK has led the world in learning to live with Covid. Freedom, with responsibility, should always be the default.

https://t.co/CJ5edCa9OK

Our Covid vaccination programme - the biggest in British history - has now delivered a record-breaking 120 MILLION doses in England, helping us live with the virus.

If you are yet to received your first, second or booster dose – it’s never too late.

https://t.co/1tG5lkUofM https://t.co/SPUkng5leY

We have secured more antivirals per head than any other European country.

Both of our ground-breaking antivirals are available to the most vulnerable to Covid through the NHS.

It's great to see 30,000 people in England already reaping the benefits.

https://t.co/fmpXkXXSvY

We will continue to provide symptomatic testing for:

👉🏽 People in high-risk services like NHS staff, social care staff & residents

We know health outcomes are disproportionately worse among deprived communities and by opening 40 new centres in all parts of England we are levelling up access to vital tests and scans. 5/5

The centres will provide an extra 2.8 million scans in their first year. 

This will help catch diseases like cancer earlier when they are easier to treat, by giving patients direct access to the full range of modern diagnostic tests. 4/5

Community Diagnostic Centres will help reduce waiting lists by housing a range of services in one dedicated and convenient location. 
 
This will mean you’re less likely to have cancelled appointments due to COVID-19, and major acute hospitals can focus on urgent care. 3/5

These one stop shops will be open 7 days a week in places like football stadiums and shopping centres and will make it easier to get checked.

This is a new approach, based on recommendations from Professor Sir Mike Richards. 2/5

Pleased to announce the rollout of 40 new Community Diagnostic Centres across England today, which we’re backing with £350million. 1/5

ENDS

Which is an excellent opportunity to share this beautiful foreword from Josh, a very talented member of our Survivors Working Group.
 
(9/10) https://t.co/VwMrMRQkiX

The project has been a labour of love for me, and for the outstanding individuals I’ve had the pleasure of working on it with.
 
I’d like to thank our expert Commissioners, and the talented, courageous group of survivors who have shaped our work from start to finish.
 
(8/10)

💼 Finally, it asks for an Independent Child Sexual Abuse Commissioner and a new Cabinet Committee, to make sure that meaningful action is taken to protect some of the most precious members of our society.
 
(7/10)

💥 It asks for new laws to combat live streaming – a particularly insidious form of abuse.
 
🤝 It calls for the victim’s law to be introduced, guaranteeing victims’ rights and the support they can expect.
 
(6/10)

👮‍ It supports proactive policing to prevent shocking failures like the grooming gangs scandal.
 
👩🏾‍⚕️ It suggests ways of making sure we don’t miss when children are being abused - including through an increase in the number of trained school nurses.
 
(5/10)

🧑‍⚖️ It includes ways of tackling a culture of weak to non-existent sentencing for abusers.
 
👨‍👩‍👧 It suggests how we can better support victims to fight for the justice. 
 
🚫 It argues against victims bearing the punishment for crimes they were coerced to commit.
 
(4/10)

The report makes 96 actionable, cross-govt policy recommendations:
 
🙅🏼‍♂️ It identifies loopholes that registered sex offenders are using to stay under the radar. These can be fixed.
 
👩🏽‍💻 It sets out a blueprint for how tech companies can better protect children online.
 
(3/10)

Today, we publish the final report.
 
Its findings are uncomfortable in places.
 
However, as well as hard truths I believe it offers a sense of hope. This problem isn’t insurmountable. There’s much more we can do.
 
(2/10)

Our country is facing an epidemic of child sexual abuse.

President Macron rightly warned about intolerant 'separatism' two weeks before Samuel Paty was murdered.

We cannot afford to wait for another tragedy to tackle extremism and reaffirm our values, as I argued recently:

https://t.co/DhRnAGAdIq

In this country we are free to peacefully follow, preach or query any religion or none.

These are hard-won freedoms that must be upheld by all public institutions. Reports of intimidation in Batley set a deeply unsettling and potentially dangerous precedent.

We are a generous, welcoming country with a strong sense of fairness.

Prof Dasgupta’s commendable review shows that our path of fast-declining biodiversity is fraught with economic uncertainty.

The UK has an opportunity to lead by example, and to help steer the global community towards a more sustainable, prosperous future. [4/4] #DasguptaReview

Nature is more than an economic good - this year many of us have discovered the restorative power of our wild places.

Many ecosystems are at tipping point or damaged beyond repair. One in four species is at risk of extinction. Once gone, these are impossible to recover. [3/4]

A healthy economy is dependent on a healthy planet, which is why risk of global demand far exceeding nature’s ability to supply is so concerning.

Damaging nature’s productivity & adaptability fuels economic risk, threatening the long-term prosperity of future generations. [2/4]

Biodiversity is declining faster than at any time in human history.

In 2019, I asked Prof Dasgupta to carry out a landmark review into the economics of biodiversity – the first commissioned by any finance ministry in the world.

Published today: [1/4]

For the strongest possible economic recovery, we need to ease the lockdown as much as the scientific advice allows, going as fast and as far as possible.  Let’s also remember that there is only one economic model that creates prosperity and jobs… 5/

Of course, it’s right that government listens to scientific advice. But, in making decisions, ministers will want to consider broader societal factors, including the impact on jobs, incomes & opportunities. I’m also concerned about rise in domestic violence & child abuse. 4/

Small businesses, and 16M livelihoods that depend on them, are particularly vulnerable. The accumulation of longer-term damage to the economy will accelerate in coming weeks. A 4-month lockdown is not twice as bad as a 2-month lockdown. The impact will be many times more. 3/

Just as with the public health crisis, we need to hope for the best, plan for the worst. 

The PM is right to put public health first. He'll also be conscious that the longer a full lockdown is maintained, the more businesses will collapse. 2/
